Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Project-Based Learning at the African Linguistics School

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Inaugurated in 2009, the African Linguistics School (ALS) is a two-week institute held biennially. The next ALS will be held in July 2016, in Abidjan, Ivory Coast. Most of those in attendance at the school are graduate students and postdoctoral scholars in linguistics at African universities. The attendees also include graduate students from American universities. The aim of the ALS is to provide students with the latest work in core areas of linguistics. The school's students, selected through a highly competitive application process, pay no fees; the ALS covers tuition, room and board, and, for students coming from within Africa, transportation to and from the school. Faculty members, drawn from North America, Africa, and Europe, teach pro bono. The school promotes higher education through the training of outstanding graduate students who return to their institutions with knowledge that they then impart to their own colleagues and students; A number of the students go on to study at leading American graduate programs in linguistics. The ALS promotes intellectual cooperation that may lead to research collaborations among students, postdocs, and faculty, among participants from the US and different countries in Africa.

The specific goals of the current grant are to introduce project-based teaching into the ALS curriculum and to increase the diversity of the students in terms of country of origin. The format for ALS courses has been lectures, which have the advantage of providing students with a guided and highly concentrated description of the subject matter. However, especially in an intense two-week institute, there come to be limits as to how much students as audience can absorb. To address this at the next ALS, time will be reserved for projects that involve students working in teams to carry out linguistic research. The projects will focus on hands-on activities, such as eliciting data, applying standard definitions to data, and formulating and testing hypotheses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The African Linguistics School (ALS) is a two-week institute that brings the latest work in core areas of linguistics to graduate students from African universities. The areas of focus are syntax, semantics, phonology, sociolinguistics/contact linguistics, and fieldwork.

To date, the ALS has met five times: in Ghana (2009), Benin (2011), Nigeria (2013), Cote d'Ivoire (2016), and South Africa (2019).

Admission to the ALS is highly competitive. Students and a small number of recent Ph.D.s come to each ALS from all over Africa. In addition, a small number of students come to ALS from universities in Europe or North America. Apart from a nominal registration fee, all costs are covered for students and postdocs from African universities, including round-trip transportation to the site of ALS. The ALS is committed to gender equity, and at the two most recent ALSs there have been roughly even numbers of women and men, with women slightly outnumbering men.

The founding organizers of the ALS are Enoch Aboh (University of Amsterdam), Akinbiyi Akinlabi (Rutgers University), Chris Collins (New York University), and John Victor Singler (New York University). The faculty for ALS represents a mix of prominent senior scholars and promising junior scholars. They come from North America, Europe and Africa, and they teach at ALS pro bono.

At the ALS, students participate in two weeks of intense training in the core areas of linguistics through a combination of course work, presentations, projects, and individual consultation with faculty members. They develop international networks with faculty members and other students. Through ALS they gain access to a library of relevant literature. Students take what they have learned back to their host universities to share with their colleagues. After attending the ALS, some students go on to gain admission to North American and European graduate schools.

ALS4 took place on the campus of the Institut National Polytechnique F?lix Houphou?t-Boigny in Yamoussoukro, Cote d'Ivoire, in July, 2016. NSF grant 1451683, Project-Based Learning at the African Linguistics School, funded a pedagogical innovation there. The format for courses at the first three meetings of the ALS had been lectures, which had the advantage of providing students with a guided and highly concentrated description of the subject matter. However, especially in an intense two-week institute, there come to be limits as to how much students as audience can absorb. To address this at ALS4, the final timeslot of the day was given over to projects that involved students working in teams to carry out research. The projects focused on hands-on activities such as eliciting data, applying standard definitions to data, formulating and testing hypotheses, and the like.

Five projects were carried out:

  • The Syntax and Semantics of Negation
  • Topics in Nominal Syntax and the SSWL [Syntactic Structures of the World's Languages] Database
  • Investigations into the Structure of Dan [a Mande language]
  • Phonetic Field Methods [using Wobe, a Kru language]
  • Urban Youth Vernaculars in Africa, Number Marking, and Sociolinguistics

The heightened participation and interaction of students, among themselves and with faculty members, made for highly effective learning. The NSF grant funded increased participation from across the continent, enabling larger numbers of students and postdocs to come by air from eastern and southern Africa, Cameroon, and Nigeria. Thus, the projects drew from a wide range of African languages.
